bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Joseph A. LePrince, June 2, 1916

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Joseph A. LePrince, June 2, 1916
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
BALTIMORE, MD.
June 2, 1916.
Dear LePrince:
div1.p:
The Catawba Dam (Great Falls) will be closed about
August 1st. It will take from 7 to 14 days to fill--unless there
be a freshet. We will then be able to make the preliminary sur-
vey to determine the quadrimaculatus production of the environ-
ment before filling, in a very decent time of the year. Not so
good as at Whitney, but pretty good. I agreed to communicate
with the Company --Southern Power Co., Charlotte, N. C.--about
July 20th., but July 15th. would be better.

Allowing 14 days at that time of the year from egg to
imago, we can take larvae up to 14 after the pond is formed
(from eggs deposited) unaffected by the pond's existence. I
think we ought to begin work about July 20th. Griffitts has
all of this data. The pond is only 6 miles longt to live water--
4 1/2 out of banks. The Company are enthusiastic and “muy sim-
patica.” I think it will pay to put considerable time on this
proposition. Also, this Company will shortly make a pond at
Camden, S. C. which is in about the same position as Parr's
Shoals with regard to topography and hence an ideal place for our
work to determine the effect of a pond on the preferential breed-
ing of quadrimaculatus. This for next year.

Griffitts will be in charge of the Impounded Waters
work until you join him. He will have two men (Haynes and Ran-
-2-
kin's brother) and a “cullud pusson” to row the boat when needed.
Launch out of commission.

I think there will be time enough for
(1) A good survey of environment of Great Falls Pond
(2) Same of Whitney including the breeding area in
the Canal and some other places which will be covered by the pond.
(3) A wind-up--September--about the Coosa, examin-
ing the country outside of pond influence for quad. breeding: as
at Shelby; back of Sulphur Mountain: Talladega; near Clanton;
down the river two to five miles below the dam etc. This to see
the species present in the country generally, independent of the
pond. This, of course, is what Griffitts is going to do for Parr
Shoals, but the season is not late enough for best results. I
Think quads. are just about to begin production then, i. e. we
find a little pond breeding, but very little and mainly small
larvae. A few pupae, however, and some good sized ones in some
particularly sunny places. Plenty in running streams. No flight
mosquitoes observed on the celluloid sheet put out one night in
The Guest House window--134 small insects--chironomedae mainly.
It had been better to have come to Parr 10 days sooner, but I
think we are at the beginning of quad. production there if we
have not preceeded it.

I hope that von Ezdorf may be able to go with our party
--you and Griffitts--to the Great Falls pond. Shew him this let-
ter please.

Oh! it is not impossible that when you have been to
Emporia you may be asked to visit a pond giving trouble near Nor-
-3-
folk, Va. The owners want to remedy conditions complained of and
are able to do so. I advised Dr. Williams of Va. to take up the
matter with Dr. von Ezdorf or the Bureau. It would delay your
going to Parr, but this would do not harm for--say--a week.

Good luck to you and I am sorry not be with you this
summer, yet I am glad to get into yellow fever work once more too.
div1.closer: Very truly your friend, Assistant Surgeon General. HRC/LC
